q: What is bursitis?
a: Bursitis is when a joint becomes painful and swollen due to inflammation of the fluid-filled sacs (bursa) that cushion the joints.

q: How can I check if I have bursitis?
a: You might have bursitis if one of your joints is painful, tender, swollen, and more painful when you move it or press on it. The affected area may also be red.

q: What are the self-treatment options for bursitis?
a: To treat bursitis at home, you can rest the joint, apply ice to reduce swelling, and take painkillers such as paracetamol or ibuprofen. It may also help to use extra cushions while sleeping to support the affected joint.

q: When should I see a GP for bursitis?
a: You should see a GP if your symptoms have not improved or are getting worse after treating it yourself for 1 to 2 weeks, if you have a high temperature or feel hot and shivery, if you cannot move the affected joint, or if you have severe, sharp, or shooting pains in the joint.

q: What happens at a GP appointment for bursitis?
a: At a GP appointment for bursitis, they may take a sample of fluid from the affected joint using a needle for further testing. If necessary, you may be referred for other tests or to a hospital.

q: What are the treatments for bursitis?
a: Treatments for bursitis may include antibiotics if it is caused by an infection, a steroid injection to reduce swelling, and in rare cases, surgical drainage or removal of the inflamed bursa.

q: How can I prevent bursitis from coming back?
a: To prevent bursitis from recurring, maintain a healthy weight, clean any cuts on elbows and knees to prevent infections, warm up properly before exercising, use padding when putting pressure on joints, and take regular breaks during activities that stress the joints.
